content.description: Reaction 1: <math alttext="X is in equilibrium with Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Reaction 2: <math alttext="X is in equilibrium with Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> undergoes the two competing reactions represented above. The following graph shows the changes in energy that occur as the two reactions take place.
content.question: In an experiment done at a low temperature, one hour after the reaction started, <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></math> was produced but almost no <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math> was produced. At a much higher temperature, one hour after the reaction started, both <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math> had been produced. Which of the following best explains why very little <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math> was produced at the lower temperature?

choices.label: A smaller number of <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules had enough energy to overcome the activation energy barrier for reaction 2, and very little <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math> was produced.

The higher average kinetic energy of the <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules at the lower temperature resulted in very little <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math> produced.

The greater collision frequency between <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules at the lower temperature resulted in very little <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math> produced.

The intermolecular forces between <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules were much weaker, and very little <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math> was produced.

content.answer: A smaller number of <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules had enough energy to overcome the activation energy barrier for reaction 2, and very little <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math> was produced.

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
